elements.name: To understand the use of Json path expressions

doc_string.value:
21:51:02.734 request:
1 > GET http://localhost:8080/normal/webapi/all
1 > Accept: application/json
1 > Host: localhost:8080
1 > Connection: Keep-Alive
1 > User-Agent: Apache-HttpClient/4.5.13 (Java/19.0.1)
1 > Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate


21:51:03.385 response time in milliseconds: 646
1 < 200
1 < X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff
1 < X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block
1 < Cache-Control: no-cache, no-store, max-age=0, must-revalidate
1 < Pragma: no-cache
1 < Expires: 0
1 < X-Frame-Options: DENY
1 < Content-Type: application/json
1 < Transfer-Encoding: chunked
1 < Date: Sun, 19 Mar 2023 16:21:03 GMT
1 < Keep-Alive: timeout=60
1 < Connection: keep-alive
[{"jobId":1,"jobTitle":"Software Engg","jobDescription":"To develop andriod application","experience":["Google","Apple","Mobile Iron"],"project":[{"projectName":"Movie App","technology":["Kotlin","SQL Lite","Gradle"]}]}]

steps.name: def jobTitles = karate.jsonPath(response,"$[?(@.jobId > 10)].jobTitle")
comments: #Below expression evaluates the response and filters out those objects in the response array which have
# jobId greater than 10 and stores the jobTitle values in a variable
#Below we are validating that jobTitles array received in the previous step has size more than 1
steps.name: match jobTitles == '#?_.length > 1'

doc_string.value:
21:51:03.721 classpath:com/api/automation/getRequest/karateJsonpath.feature:15
And match jobTitles == '#?_.length > 1'
match failed: EQUALS
  $ | evaluated to 'false' (LIST:STRING)
  []
  '#?_.length > 1'

classpath:com/api/automation/getRequest/karateJsonpath.feature:15

name: com/api/automation/getRequest/karateJsonpath.feature
description: Use of json path in karate framework
